title: Headache (Cephalalgia)
content: A headache is pain or discomfort in the head, scalp, or neck. Common types include tension headaches, migraines, and cluster headaches. Most headaches are not serious and can be treated with pain relievers, relaxation techniques, and lifestyle changes.
what_to_do: Rest in a dark, quiet room
Over-the-counter pain relievers may help (consult pharmacist)
do_not: Do not ignore sudden severe headaches
Do not take pain relievers more than 2-3 days/week regularly
Do not self-diagnose migraines without doctor consultation
red_flags: Headache with fever and stiff neck
Headache with confusion or vision changes
when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate medical attention (112) if headache is sudden and severe, accompanied by fever, stiff neck, confusion, seizures, double vision, weakness, numbness, or difficulty speaking.

title: Fever (Pyrexia)
content: A fever is a temporary increase in body temperature, often due to illness. A temperature above 38C (100.4F) is generally considered a fever. Fever is a sign that your body is fighting an infection.
what_to_do: Rest and stay hydrated (water, clear fluids)
Fever reducers may help (consult pharmacist for appropriate use)
do_not: Do not use ice baths or very cold water
Do not bundle up in heavy blankets despite chills
Do not give aspirin to children under 16
Do not ignore high fever (above 39.4C/103F)
when_to_see_doctor: Seek medical attention for fever above 39.4C (103F), fever lasting more than 3 days, severe headache, stiff neck, confusion, persistent vomiting, difficulty breathing, or skin rash.

title: Sore Throat (Pharyngitis)
content: A sore throat is pain, scratchiness, or irritation of the throat that often worsens when swallowing. The most common cause is a viral infection (cold or flu). Bacterial infections like strep throat require antibiotic treatment prescribed by a doctor.
symptoms: Pain or scratchy sensation in throat
do_not: Do not demand antibiotics for viral infections
Do not give honey to children under 1 year
Do not smoke or expose to secondhand smoke
Do not ignore symptoms lasting more than a week
red_flags: Voice changes lasting more than 2 weeks
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if sore throat is severe or lasts longer than a week, difficulty swallowing or breathing, high fever, blood in saliva, frequent sore throats, or lump in neck.

title: Cough
content: A cough is your body's way of responding to irritants in your throat and airways. Occasional coughing is normal, but a persistent cough can indicate an underlying condition. Coughs can be dry or productive (with mucus).
what_to_do: Use honey for cough (adults and children over 1)
do_not: Do not give honey to children under 1 year
Do not suppress a productive cough unnecessarily
Do not smoke
Do not ignore cough lasting more than 3 weeks
when_to_see_doctor: Seek medical attention for cough lasting more than 3 weeks, coughing up blood, difficulty breathing, high fever, unexplained weight loss, or night sweats.

title: Stomach Pain (Abdominal Pain)
content: Abdominal pain refers to discomfort in the area between the chest and pelvis. Most cases are not serious and can be related to digestion, but severe pain may indicate a serious condition requiring immediate attention.
what_to_do: Avoid solid food for a few hours if nauseous
Heat pad on abdomen may help
Ginger or peppermint tea for mild symptoms
do_not: Do not take aspirin or ibuprofen on empty stomach
Do not ignore severe or sudden pain
Do not eat heavy or fatty foods
Do not take laxatives for undiagnosed abdominal pain
when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care (112) for severe pain, pain with fever, bloody stool, persistent vomiting, swollen abdomen, pain during pregnancy, or pain lasting more than 24-48 hours.

title: Back Pain
content: Back pain is one of the most common medical problems. It can range from a dull, constant ache to sudden, sharp pain. Most back pain gets better within a few weeks without treatment.
what_to_do: Sleep on firm surface with pillow under knees
do_not: Do not stay in bed for extended periods
Do not lift heavy objects
Do not ignore pain radiating down legs
Do not self-treat chronic back pain without evaluation
red_flags: Pain spreading down legs (especially below knee)
Loss of bladder or bowel control
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if pain persists beyond a few weeks, is severe and doesn't improve with rest, spreads down legs (especially below knee), causes weakness/numbness/tingling, or is accompanied by unexplained weight loss.

title: Chest Pain
content: Chest pain can have many causes, from muscle strain to heart problems. While not all chest pain is serious, it's important to recognize when it might indicate a heart attack or other emergency. When in doubt, seek immediate medical attention.
symptoms: Pain spreading to arm, jaw, or back
what_to_do: If suspected heart attack: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY
Note when pain started and characteristics
do_not: Do NOT delay calling emergency services if heart attack suspected
Do NOT drive yourself to hospital
Do NOT ignore chest pain, especially with risk factors
Do NOT take someone else's heart medication
red_flags: Pain spreading to arm, jaw, neck, or back
Chest pain with shortness of breath
Chest pain lasting more than a few minutes
when_to_see_doctor: CALL 112 IMMEDIATELY if chest pain is sudden and severe, accompanied by shortness of breath, pain spreading to arm/jaw/back, sweating, nausea, or dizziness. These could be signs of a heart attack.

title: Nausea and Vomiting
content: Nausea is an uneasiness of the stomach that often comes before vomiting. Vomiting is the forcible emptying of stomach contents through the mouth. These symptoms can be caused by many conditions.
what_to_do: Rest and avoid solid foods temporarily
Sip clear fluids slowly (water, clear broth)
BRAT diet when ready (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast)
Avoid lying flat - slightly elevated position
do_not: Do not force yourself to eat
Do not drink large amounts at once
Do not eat spicy or fatty foods
Do not ignore signs of dehydration
red_flags: Blood in vomit (looks like coffee grounds)
Stiff neck with headache and vomiting
when_to_see_doctor: Seek medical care if vomiting persists more than 24 hours, there's blood in vomit, signs of dehydration, severe abdominal pain, high fever, or stiff neck with headache.

title: Dizziness
content: Dizziness is a term used to describe a range of sensations including feeling faint, woozy, weak, or unsteady. Vertigo creates the false sense that you or your surroundings are spinning or moving.
do_not: Do not stand up quickly
Do not drive if dizzy
Do not climb ladders or heights
Do not ignore recurring dizziness
when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care (112) if dizziness is accompanied by sudden severe headache, chest pain, difficulty breathing, numbness/weakness, fainting, rapid heartbeat, or head injury.

title: Fatigue
content: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness that can be physical, mental, or both. It's different from simply feeling drowsy or sleepy. Fatigue can be a symptom of many different conditions.
do_not: Do not rely on caffeine or energy drinks
Do not ignore persistent fatigue
Do not skip meals
Do not overwork without rest
red_flags: Fatigue lasting more than 2 weeks despite rest
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if fatigue persists despite rest, is accompanied by unexplained weight loss, fever, or other symptoms, significantly impacts daily life, or if you suspect an underlying condition.

title: Common Cold
content: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. It's usually harmless, although it might not feel that way. Many types of viruses can cause a common cold, with rhinoviruses being the most common.
causes: Spread through droplets or touching contaminated surfaces
what_to_do: Honey for cough (adults and children over 1)
do_not: Do not demand antibiotics (ineffective against viruses)
Do not give honey to children under 1
Do not share personal items
Do not go to work/school when contagious
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if symptoms last more than 10 days, high fever (above 39.4C/103F), fever returning after improvement, severe sinus pain, or difficulty breathing.

title: Influenza (Flu)
content: Influenza is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can cause mild to severe illness. The best way to prevent flu is annual vaccination.
symptoms: Vomiting and diarrhea (more common in children)
what_to_do: Symptom relief for fever and aches
Antiviral medications if prescribed early by doctor
do_not: Do not go to work/school while sick
Do not share personal items
Do not give aspirin to children under 16
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Symptoms improve then return with fever and worse cough
when_to_see_doctor: Seek emergency care for difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain, confusion, severe vomiting, or flu-like symptoms that improve but return with fever and worse cough.

title: Diabetes Overview
content: Diabetes is a chronic disease where the body either doesn't produce enough insulin or can't effectively use the insulin it produces. This leads to elevated blood glucose levels that can damage organs over time. Proper management is essential.
causes: Type 1: Autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells
Type 2: Insulin resistance, often linked to obesity and lifestyle
do_not: Do not skip medications
Do not ignore blood sugar readings
Do not skip meals if on insulin
Do not exercise with very high blood sugar
red_flags: Nausea and vomiting with high blood sugar
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you experience symptoms of diabetes, have risk factors, or if you have diabetes and experience very high or low blood sugar, signs of ketoacidosis, or other complications.

title: High Blood Pressure (Hypertension)
content: High blood pressure is a common condition where the force of blood against artery walls is too high. It often has no symptoms but can lead to serious health problems like heart disease and stroke if untreated.
do_not: Do not skip blood pressure medications
Do not add extra salt to food
Do not ignore high readings
Do not smoke
when_to_see_doctor: Get regular blood pressure checks. Seek immediate care (112) if blood pressure is very high (180/120 or higher) or accompanied by chest pain, severe headache, difficulty breathing, or neurological symptoms.

title: Anxiety Disorders
content: Anxiety disorders involve more than temporary worry or fear. For a person with an anxiety disorder, the anxiety does not go away and can get worse over time, interfering with daily activities. Professional help is available and effective.
what_to_do: Talk to trusted people about your feelings
do_not: Do not self-medicate with alcohol or drugs
Do not isolate yourself
Do not avoid seeking professional help
Do not be ashamed - anxiety is common and treatable
when_to_see_doctor: Seek help if anxiety interferes with work, relationships, or daily life, if you have suicidal thoughts (call crisis line immediately), or if anxiety is accompanied by depression or substance use problems.

title: Depression
content: Depression is a common but serious mood disorder that affects how you feel, think, and handle daily activities. It requires treatment and is not something people can simply 'snap out of'. Effective treatments are available.
do_not: Do not isolate yourself
Do not make major decisions when severely depressed
Do not self-medicate with alcohol or drugs
Do not give up on treatment - it takes time
when_to_see_doctor: Seek help immediately (call crisis line or 112) if you have thoughts of suicide or self-harm. Also see a doctor if symptoms persist for more than two weeks, significantly impact daily functioning, or if depression returns after improvement.
crisis_info: Acil risk varsa 112'yi arayın veya en yakın acil servise gidin.
